duck: Aarhus (meteorite) - Aarhus is an H chondrite meteorite that fell to earth on October 2, 1951 in Aarhus, Denmark.

'Aarhus' or 'Århus' () is the second-largest city in Denmark. The principal port
of Denmark, Aarhus is on the east side of the peninsula of Jutland in the
geographical centre of Denmark. Aarhus is the seat of the council of Aarhus
municipality with 319,094<ref name="dst.dk"/> inhabitants and 256,018 (1 January
2013)<ref name="BEF44"/> in the inner urban area. According to Aarhus
municipality, the "Greater Aarhus" area has a population of about 1.25 million
people.<ref></ref><ref></ref><ref>http://www.aarhus.dk/~/media/Subsites/Aarhus-
Wind-Energy/Dokumenter/Working-and-
living.ashx</ref><ref>[http://www.businessaarhus.dk/~/media/Subsites/Business-
Aarhus/Powerpoint-praesentationer/Aarhus-som-vkstby-english-new.ashx ]</ref> The
city claims the unofficial title "Capital of Jutland".<ref name=CVDE>Bridgwater,
W. & Beatrice Aldrich. (1966) The Columbia-Viking Desk Encyclopædia. Columbia
University. p. 11.</ref>

Aarhus is the main and biggest city in the East Jutland metropolitan area (),
which is a co-operation in eastern Jutland with 17 municipalities.<ref name="Vis">[http://www.blst.dk/NR/rdonlyres/D57AF934-C471-41E6-A8B0-
389AF80A94A6/0/Visionsoplaeg20082008.pdf "Vision Østjylland"], Miljøministeriet,
20. august 2008 </ref> With more than 1.2 million people living in the East
Jutland metropolitan area it represents approximately 23% of the population of
Denmark. Aarhus has the second-largest urban area in Denmark after Copenhagen.<ref>[http://www2.blst.dk/udgiv/Publikationer/2008/978-87-92256-58-
4/html/kap05.htm#5.1 "Danish Befolkningsforhold i Østjylland], Miljøministeriet,
august 2008</ref>
